reviewText:
Finders is the latest of Alawar Entertainment's simulation games to find its way onto Steam.  Although a bit more casual than I usually enjoy, after getting used to the gameplay I found it to be quite a relaxing and pleasant experience.

First, let me note that if you're looking for any type of challenge, even if it's an arbitrary goal that you can impose on your own gameplay to perfect your play, this really isn't the game for you.  Finders is a true casual title in that there's no time crunch, no goal that must be met to earn yourself any type of trophy (other than some easy to reach in-game achievements), nothing at all that places stress on the player.   This lack of challenge may prove too bland for some, but those who are looking for true casualness in gameplay may find it just the thing for them.

Gameplay consists of completing various quests by directing your finders" about an area of the map
recommended: solving puzzles and leveling up which unlocks more actions
hoursPlayed: quests and options for the player.  As you build up your camp
voteText: gather resources
helpfulPercent: complete quests  and cut a path towards your overall objective
votesHelpful: a simple story unfolds giving a bit of meaning to everything you're doing.  There is an element of freedom present in that you don't necessarily have to complete any task in order
votesTotal: but to progress you will need to work through those quests. Still
votesFunny: without a ticking clock hounding you
commentsCount: you can take your time planning out moves.  Even the resource management aspect of the game is quite forgiving as you can always spend time gathering foods or other materials if you find yourself short
column16: then get back to questing without issue.\n\nMy main complaint is that the tutorial isn't quite as intuitive as it could be.  I spent quite a bit of time in the beginning trying to figure out just what I was supposed to do and what exactly the game itself entailed.  Once you have a grasp of how everything works it gets better
column17: but this may be frustrating for those looking for something easy to jump right into.\n\nFor the price
column18: Finders is worth a look if you're in the mood for casual gaming without the rush and stress that most titles in the genre employ.  Perfect for whiling away an hour here and there on lazy afternoons
column19: if only there were Steam Achievement integration of the in-game Awards
column20:
but I'll just have to be content with trading cards for now.

Bottom Line: Recommended for players looking for a truly casual experience without the usual time crunch madness of other "casual" sim games.

Note - This game was provided by the publisher with the request to write an informative review."
column24: 128 of 152 people (84%) found this review helpful 11 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Finders is a casual resource management game where you and your team of workers set out for a journey to rescue the guardian of the world, Altair. It is a lot more casual compared to other titles in the genre, for better, or worse, personally I appreciate Alawar for trying to bring a different experience to the table.

Despite being a resource management game, the levels in Finders do not have a time constraint, or even a failure state, this can be a huge turn off for some people as the game in turn offers less of a challenge. However, the game does offers you a surprising amount of freedom when it comes to building and expanding the camp and allows you advance through the level at your own pace.

The core gameplay is solid to say the least, you are given the task to complete a variety of different objectives in the game in your own time, in order to progress through the level. At first it mainly consist of setting up your camp and satisfy the basic needs of your workers, but the game opens up considerably afterwards and introduces you to a plethora of new mechanics and features, including a well made match 3 mini game, completed with power ups and abilities.

In short, Finders is a great game if youâ€™re looking for a stress free, casual experience that is chock full of quality contents thatâ€™ll keep you entertained for a fair amount of time.
voteText: 95 of 135 people (70%) found this review helpful 9 people found this review funny

reviewText:
From time-management to resource-gathering, then on to crafting and mini-games including match-3 and logic puzzles, Finders has a little from each of the casual classics. The game frames this all in an adventure story, which plays out as you accomplish goals and build up your camp and add little bits of interesting tech as you go.

Finders is an easy and relaxing game, with no time pressure or tricky strategic maneuvering to ramp up the difficulty. The game saves whenever you exit, so you can easily play in tiny increments without having to redo anything.

If you're looking for a challenge, you will probably want to look elsewhere. If you just want a relaxing experience that rewards the achievement of simple goals with a cute and colorful adventure story, then check this one out.

The trading cards are nice, but I do wish that the in-game trophies were available as Steam achievements.

A review copy of this game was provided by the publisher.

reviewText:
I like ultra-casual games.  I like time management & match 3 games, the two genres into which this game most solidly fits.  I also like city-builders.  So I should be the exact target audience for this game, but I didn't enjoy playing it.

The game tells you to complete arbitrary tasks, something like quests, and just as in (bad) RPGs, it doesn't matter if you've JUST done the arbitrary task, you still have to do it again.  The match 3 game is only really necessary when the game tells you to play it, and it's timed and impossible to strategize.  There's some strategy involved in setting up your camp, and doing your best to fine-tune it.

But here's the game's biggest flaw, in my opinion.  After fine-tuning your camp, you have to move to a new area and complete a very tedious process in order to bring some of your progress with you.   This happens several times over the course of the game.

Additionally, the fishing minigame needs to be shot out of a cannon into the sun.  Overall, this is a very annoying game.

reviewText:
***This review was written using a key provided by the Publisher for review purposes***

Finders is a casul strategy/management game from the developer of The Treasures of Montezuma. Earth was once protected by a hero named Altair, but now he has gone missing and a team of brave adventurers have gone to find him. While travelling to his last known location their helicopter crashed and it is now your job to keep these brave workers alive and help them find Altair so that Earth can be protected by him once again.

+Nice colourful graphics
+A simple and easy to navigate UI
+Finders' casual nature means that it is very relaxing to play though there is no real challenge which is only an issue if you're looking for a challenging game
+As you progress through the game the story unravels and you learn more about what has brought you to where you are and why you crashed
+You are given jobs to complete which give you direction in the game but they can be completed in any order and don't have to be done right away so you have a fair bit of freedom within the game
+Three different resources to manage which are linked to each other meaning you need to keep an eye on all of them but the game is very forgiving should you run out of any of them
+A few different environments to play in
+Buildings can be moved after they've been built which is very helpful
+Buildings can be upgraded to be more efficient or just perform their role more, e.g. generate twice as much money
+Nice relaxing soundtrack and good sound effects

-It has in-game achievements but no Steam achievements, a minor issue but one I wanted to mention
-The tutorial portion of the game felt a bit too slow to me
-You can't modify the game speed, something I felt would have been nice because collecting resources does take quite a long time

Verdict:
7.5

A fun, casual time management game with colourful graphics, a nice UI and relaxing gameplay, if you're looking for a new casual game do yourself a favour and pick this one up!

El K.
voteText: 59 of 93 people (63%) found this review helpful 7 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Finders is an addictive casual Time/Resource Management game that both feels familiar and manages to put its own unique spin on the genre.

In Finders you direct an expedition that crash lands while in search an artifact in order to help locate a lost hero.  You're left to send survivors out to gather resources and build up the camp in order to continue the mission, which has 4 separate chapters.

Where Finders diverges from many other casual time management games is that it's area based rather than level based and you get to stay in one area for a long time. I found I liked this style of gameplay a bit better than hurrying through multiple levels as I felt more invested in gradually improving my camp and gathering resources since I would be there for some time.

You get a constant stream of mini goals that usually involve building or gathering resources and in some cases may even include short puzzles. Some of these will further the campaign along while others or merely optional goals to allow an opportunity to gain experience and levels.

The pace of the game is relaxed (with one exception; more on that later) and seeing the camp grow over time made the game fun and addictive for me. In addition to the building, upgrading and resource gathering there are a couple of mini-games.

Most notably is the mining mini-game which is done as a match 3 game. These segments are timed which and I found much more hectic than the pace of the rest of the game. It's worth noting though that they are mostly optional as there are few places in the game where you're required to do it to progress and there's no real penalty for not getting very far down in the game other than using some of your water resource, which is replaceable. You can also retry as many times as you like.

The other main mini game is fishing. It's a bit of a timing mouse click sort of mini-game that's pretty quick and fairly simple once you get the hang of it, but again this is optional and later in the game you get access to a boat you can use to gather fish without doing the mini-game.

One area I thought could have been handled a little better were the transitions between areas. You don't take money you've earned over. You can take your resources but you have to transport each resource separately by helicopter which is a bit slow and tedious as well as carries a per item fee, but you do get the option at least to bring some items over. It's all optional however as you can just as well play from scratch in the new area and there's some things you can do to maximize effeciency in transporting previous accumulations like buying up lots of the most expensive items and then selling them at the new camp.

Overall I really enjoyed Finders and found myself wanted to go back, build up my camp and progress through the campaign and its quirky story right up until the end.

reviewText:
Finders:
~~~~~~~
Altair is missing!! Since his disappearance phenomenon, the likes of earthquake have become more frequent, even animals react strangely. We need to find Altair, this hero who is well known for his good deeds. Our only hope is to retrieve an artefact that may guide us to his whereabouts. Your mission is to find him.

Finders, is a casual management / strategy game where you have to achieve tasks to be able to move further into the story. In some instances, you will play a match 3 types puzzle game to collect specifics resources.

There is plenty things to do in this game, your workers will have to build tents, braziers, barbecues, kitchens, wells, storages etc. Also, you will have to gather plenty of resources like foods, wood, stone and herbs to make a revitalizing cup of tea! You can take your jeep to town to sell or buy articles that you may need to achieve a task in progress.   However, keep in mind that every action will cost you food and you must keep this resource well stocked.

You will be able to get some interesting item at the shop. For example, you might need a helicopter, a plane or a truck. All articles in the shop cost money but you must achieve a specific level to be able to purchase some of them.

Finders is very easy to master and will appeal to players who enjoy a good casual game.

The graphics are nice and the game runs well.

Positives:
~~~~~~~~

-	Nice graphics
-	Plenty of things to do
-	Easy to master
-	Nice combination of management /strategy and match 3 type a gameplay
-	Achievements
-	Trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	A bit repetitive

In a nutshell, a good casual game.

8/10

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

reviewText:
A very nice, very casual, but highly involving resource gathering/management game.

It's not a time management game, as you can do any given task at any time, in any order, totally at your leisure.

It's hard to pigeon-hole this game to any specific genre. It's not a Virtual Villager clone as there is no set roles for your people, no skills or anything. You just have whomever is available do the job you need done.

It's a pretty long game IMO, as I've put in eight hours already and am only in the second area. It has a main storyline quest, lots of side quests, and quite a few items to buy and upgrade.

It has some mini-puzzle events, but in keeping with its casual theme, no brain cells will be harmed in doing them and they do fit in with the game, such as match-three for tunneling into mines to find ore.

All in all it is exactly as described in the description. It's a fun, addictive casual game that just wants to entertain and involve the player, and it does so very well. Highly, highly recommended.

reviewText:
Hello All,

First for the price you get a much more involved game than you would think.  So far I haven't seen any bugs that I can tell, and its got good game play.

This game has one major drawback that I didn't see others mention, the constant clicking.  You have to micro manage everything, constantly.  Now most of us are used to that in some fashion in these type of games, but this is where the short cuts where taken, no matter what about every 20 seconds you have to click on everything that produces food, water, or cash, as well as all the resources that respawn for your workers to go harvest/collect.  This gets old fast.  clicklety click click click.  Thats all you do in this game.  keep clicking on the same tree, bush, same everything every 15 to 20 seconds as it respawns.

Even using the resources you gather, every few seconds click on the kitchen, to make more stuff, no auto queing.  After 10 hours I was clicked out.  Just way to much clicking.   That said, if you can suffer through that, the rest of it is as others said a fun little game.

if the workers would be auto gather on where you send them once, and the wells, tents, and grills would auto collect after the first upgrade, that would make the game much more tolerable.


Edit the next day ... ok so once you get to level 19 ... you get a reprieve from most of the clicking.  They finally give you a perk where you only have to click on one tent, or one water well, or one brazier, and you collect everything from them all.  Also by that time, you aren't so desparate for collecting the respawning wood stone and food as much so the game play is much more enjoyable.


I finished the game today ...  nice game, well wortth the price, but i don't see any real replay ability.   I also got the feeling like I had played this game before or one very very similiar.

I would highly suggest they patch this and put that once click resource perk so you get it before you leave the first island, that would really make the game play much more enjoyable.

Also for you planners who like to max resources before you jump to the next new place ... um as far as food, water and cash go ... don't bother , you basically start over each time.  When you get to the third place .... thats when its worth really going for it, and purchasing most of the big stuff.

Enjoy, looking forward to a second one.

reviewText:
Finders is a bit different from the usual Alawar strategy/management games (of which I have played many).
Untimed with infinite resources. By infinite, I mean there is always a way to get more of what you need.
Different actions require certain resources and time. Some tasks are done quickly while others can take minutes.
Buildings can be freely placed on an isometric grid. There aren't dedicated spots like most Alawar strategies.
There is a decent number of types of resources that each have a purpose.
Cooking can be done to use resources/ingredients to make food and stat boost items (faster workers, etc).
Smelting to make more valuable ingots to sell for money.
All items can be sold to raise money. Some ingredients can only be obtained by buying them from town.
Later in the game, there are demand spikes that make random items worth 3x more than usual. Selling in-demand items is a good way to raise the money required for the very expensive vehicles, upgrades, etc.
Random, optional objectives will appear that provide rewards if completed.
The graphics have a bit more detail than the usual Alawar cartoony style.
There are also different mini games inside of the overall resource gathering and building part:
Bejeweled-style Match 3 game for mining : 3 blocks is a standard clear, 4 gives one type of power up, and 5 gives a stronger one. Ore is trapped in the dirt that is cleared as blocks are matched beside them.
Fishing mini-game : A dialog appears when a fishing spot is clicked. Bread (crafted) is used as bait. Different type of fish can be caught. One of them is used in crafting, and the others are either used just to replenish food or sell for money.
Alchemy-style puzzles : There aren't many, but some objectives require this type of puzzle to be completed. A pile of items are shown, and they have to be combined in the right order to meet the objective. Doing it without making mistakes will get you a money bonus.
A few different types of logic puzzles  : By no means are they brain-bending, but there are a few other puzzles to complete as objectives.
There are some things that keep this from being a perfect casual game, but I wouldn't call them cons.
Some of the words used are a bit odd. It's obvious that they are a case of lost in translation". For instance
recommended: the action you take is "Put Out". That sounds like something you do on a date. I would expect "Cast"
voteText: etc. Landing the fish is done with "Strike". I would expect "Reel In" as the action. There are also a few oddities in the in-game achievement descriptions.\nThere are in-game achievements that could've easily been implemented as Steam achievements. I like going after achievements
helpfulPercent: and I completed all of them in the game. It would be nice if they were also in my achievement collection.\nI really liked the game. It was about as long as I expect almost any Alawar title to be
votesHelpful: and the overall variety made it a bit more than a reskinned resource/time/worker management game. I got this game on sale for $1.49
votesTotal: and it was definitely worth it. The full price isn't too bad
votesFunny:
either.

On a side note: I'd like to know how people are getting keys to publish reviews of partial play-throughs. I review fully-completed games for free. :P

---

reviewText: An otherwise pleasant casual game RUINED by a STUPID random luck quest for a f@#$ing blue trout".  Avoid like the plague."
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Fun casual game. A little bit of everything and well worth buying, especially on sale. If you enjoy the build, collect, mini-quest, mini-puzzle type of game, this is for you.  Promised Land is my very favourite of the genre so far (and arguably goes beyond the genre), but this predecessor game provides several hours of engaging relaxation.  Some moments of humour, although the story is relatively superficial (but it's not supposed to be literature!).

Yes, it does look and feel a little bit like a Facebook (or similar) game, but it's nicely put together and I enjoy playing these games outside the freeware - must have a hundred online friends help you unlock cool stuff - or spend money" - setting.

The interface is slightly sless intuitive than I would have liked

Oh, god. I went from Starcraft 2 and Elite Dangerous to this casual brainless game...and I even liked it :-D

Ok, seriously: it's really a basic management game, you can finish it with a very little amount of strategy, but...dunno, it's entertaining somehow! Graphic is good, sound is too, there is some kind of story, and you can really put a bit of strategy and thought in it. So, if you want something fun, easy and relaxing to spend a bit of time, go for this.

Just one warning, the only somehow negative point in the game: the side missions are NOT needed to complete the game nor they are related to the plot, as they are totally random generated and a lot repetitive. There is no need to do them and no side effects, they are good just for the reward.
I write this 'cause spending too much time on the side missions (as I did before understanding that they where totally random) can lend to boredom (been there, seen that :-\ ) and ruin a bit the experience of an otherwise really fine game.

Thumbs up for Finders :-)
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Finders is a game of resource gathering, camp building, making and selling products, and a few mini-games, all wrapped up in a multi-stage search and rescue quest. Finders has no time pressure or levels": you get to choose whether and how you challenge yourself. (Me
recommended:
but everyone's different.)

The gathering, building, and production have just enough depth to keep me playing 10 (or 20, or 30) minutes longer than I intended, but they're simple enough that you can fit in short sessions between other tasks. The game isn't too short, either: following the entire story line took me more than a few hours.

In fact, Finders is one of the most enjoyable casual resource management games I've played in quite a while. If the art, sounds, and writing were polished, I think this could easily be a top seller. As it is, some of the art is fine and some is weak, much of the text is awkwardly translated, and the fishing mini-game needs work to be more than just a chore. If those kind of things bother you, don't get the game. But if you like clicking to gather and craft, especially with no time pressure, you're likely to enjoy this.
